I have a daughter. And she was bullied. She hated school (because of the bullying) and suffered from depression.
I don't think either gender has it easy these days. We live in a very intense world and what kids have to navigate as they grow is more complex than it ever was.
Reading your essay carefully, I sense you are a man with great sensitivity who is uncomfortable with the traditional perceptions of what our culture defines as masculine. Is it possible you wanted a girl because you are more comfortable with them, and had bad experiences with bullying from boys yourself? I can assure you, girls can bully, and be bullied, in ways that are emotionally horrific.
Your example at the end has many angles. It may be my own tendency but what I sensed from reading it is your son exhibited a certain raw energy he couldn't rein in, and which made you uncomfortable. He aped your language (you handed him an excuse when you said you weren't paying attention to him) to get past a difficult moment.

It seems that you are right in theory but things are changing
The American creed was always based in the idea that inequality is good for growth. The importance is precisely to look for whether my pension still exists and whether I still have my health care. If I still have that, then American common sense would say who cares about the 1 percent living in high living standards.
Now that American common sense is beginning to change.
Why? I dont know.
Thomas Pikety's book would have made such an impact in America 20 years ago. The question of inequality has came to the fore.
Europeanization of America?
Maybe the Trump phenomena is a message in that direction

@Bruce

A great post. The truth always lies in the middle; and, yes, we are overly sensitive to a whiff of socialism. It has polarized the nation and rendered us incapable of making any decisions.

In the end, you wouldn't need "socialism" if human kindness were innate and universal. However, simply declaring that it is not so should not be an opportunity to either institutionalize our response OR throw up our hands and insist on freedom.

The funny thing about "freedom" is that we use that, too, to achieve disparate ends. The "right" says the freedom allows me to do what I want as I want. The "left" says that freedom allows me to do what I want and it will have no effect on you so stay out of my business.

Again, both ends foster misunderstanding and, occasionally, lies.

Gee Bruce -- how'd your PARENT or GRANDPARENTS manage? do you think they got free day care, courtesy of the taxpayers? Did they get month long vacations? Some did not even own their own home. My parents did, but my mom was raised in a series of apartments. My maternal grandparents could not afford their own home until 1954, and then it was a tiny, tiny bungalow with 2 bedrooms on a tiny lot.

My grandmother worked alright -- in a knitwear sweatshop when she came to the US in 1919. She got married in 1921 and had my mom in 1926. HER mother (my Great Nana) raised my mother from infancy. Common then -- fairly common still now. I have a niece who just had her first baby, and her mother in law has retired specifically to stay home and care for the baby until she is age 5 and in kindergarten.

So people do manage -- then and now. Most of the whinging I notice is NOT from the poor or the working class -- it is from very upper middle class, upper income white professional women, who are furiously angry to find themselves "stuck" with childcare and responsibility when they finally decide to have their first baby at 39, after 20 years of "ambivalence". They want someone else -- anyone else -- to dump the hard, grotty work of child rearing on!

I don't have any kids. That ship has sailed for me. As an observer of modern parenting, I honestly don't see how people can make it. The costs are so astronomical, unless there is upwards of $80,000 coming in, what do families use for money? School, doctors, clothes, daycare, transportation, and oh yeah, a house to live in. No time off, no help, nothing.

We have a tremendous fear in this nation of socialism. The right takes the position that anything the government does to assist in child rearing somehow robs us of our freedom. I don't get it.

Instead we want profits to pay for child rearing services. But we don't want to tax profits because that's socialism. We don't want to tax the super rich because that's wealth redistribution which is socialism. We don't want to raise minimum wages because that will reduce profits which is socialism.

We point to an expanding deficit as an insurmountable problem. It is insurmountable because we wont reign in healthcare costs, which would reduce profits for the healthcare cabal, which is socialism. We wont raise Social Security taxes slightly to make it solvent for the rest of the century because that's socialism.

We give corporations the status of people but we wont tax them because that's socialism. We give the military anything it wants so we can fight the commie socialists.

We have socialism on the run, but we forgot about the reason we exist...
the kids.
WOW!

You can't get blood from a stone, and you can't rebuild if a flood has washed everything down river. In India, my mother used to cook pumpkin curry as well as prepare a dessert using pumpkin and sugar. If you mash the pumpkin into a paste,say, like mashed potatoes, and roast it with sugar till it is dry, it makes a delicius, chewy dessert. Even at the age of 70 now, I still savor the taste and crave for it. Last year around Thanksgiving time in the Washington area, I bought a couple of cans of pumpkin and tried to make the dessert. I loved it.

My mother also used to prepare a salty Indian pumpkin curry using onions and tomatoes as the base with the ususal Indian spices - turmeric, corriender, ginger, cumin powder, and garam masala. My wife cooked it for me a couple of times at my request here in Wash. This Thanksgiving I'm going to try both dishes, the curry and the pumpkin dessert. Unfortunately I never watched my mother or wife cook the curry, I have however a good idea about as to how they did it. (Last year my beloved wife passed away. But there are days I prepare one of my wife's favorite diish to think of her more intensely. My preparations never come out as good, but I enjoy the cooking part and the time it takes to do it, as during the cooking my thoughts stay totally fixated on memories of the two most wonderful ladies in my life). I wish everyone has memories to cherish for ever and ever. At moments like those, I truly come to feel my wife's presence in the kitchen smiling and watching me go through my silly, awkward motions. I have come to love cooking.
Alex even wrote a CV for the family, heavy on our respect for Japanese culture and, especially, cuisine.  Still, "no sushi for you!"

I'd do anything to be in that shop now!

Unfortunately, one won't see any mass import of Cuban cigars anytime soon and cigar aficionados will still pay relatively high prices [30 dollars a piece for a good one] for these sought after smokes.
Several factors at play:
Supply: Over 70% of Cuban cigars are exported to Spain.
FDA Regulations governing tobacco: Due to the embargo- Cuba has no grandfather clause status and would be subject to the new FDA guidelines on tobacco products. Currently there is no legal way to import any for commercial distribution. This would require Congressional jiggery-pookery to skirt these regulations.

When Ed writes that only "the lowest" among men behave in this way, perhaps he is unaware of just how prevalent the sexual harassment of women is. My own experience taught me to be wary of men of all sorts—teachers, doctors, bosses and, of course, men on the street and particularly in the subway. The point is that a woman can never let down her guard, and this is no way to live.

Fortunately Barack Obama turned out to be a great president. Hillary Clinton will win this time and also be a great president.  How this equals misogyny at the DNC is beyond me.  OF course with Drumpf you not only get misogyny, but racism, xenophobia, homophobia, antisemitism, Islamophobia, and given 5 minutes I am sure we could easily find some more phobias and isms.

Point them to this column. It's up to you if you want to reveal your identity. Not everyone can handle private stuff. In my own life, which has had  sexually demeaning situations that I put myself in, I have shared this with my daughter but not my son. He may never be able to understand.
I am so sorry this happened to you.

You do not have to do anything that doesn't feel right for you. You allowed to keep private what you wish to remain private (and privacy is an essential constitutional right).

If you feel that it would help them if they were to encounter a situation where they needed to push back (as might have Billy Bush have against Trump), and if you are comfortable relinquishing your privacy, then maybe revealing some of these experiences might help.

Mind and body are intimately entwined. If we are to support a woman's autonomy to control her body, we should as fervently support her emotional autonomy. It is your right to reveal or conceal as you feel best. No woman, no human, should feel approbation for the choices they make in this regard.

I guess I'd forgotten the number of times I've been harassed and even assaulted by men of all ages in my life. It's something you just kind of put behind you - you're expected to put behind you - I guess.  But here I am a grown-up woman with a father, brothers, husband and sons. Some right wing, some left.  None of them know of these incidences, but they sure all know better than to claim me as their reason to protest violence against women. So if anything they've learned over the past week to speak for themselves and common decency.  But I have to say this week has brought up many unhappy memories. How will I know when the time is right to tell my sons?  Do I have to?

Plenty to be enraged about! Frightened serves the misogynist's agenda.

Having experienced rape at age 18, I first retreated into fright and mistrust until I realized that was the rapist's goal. To exert a man's power. Then I got angry. Very angry. I vowed that I would push back against the fear, the mistrust, the self-doubt. That I would not allow him to rob me of neither my humanity nor my womanhood.

Now at 60 years old, a physician who has dealt the best I can with the misogynist slings and arrows of a professional woman's life, who tries to help children and adolescents deal with racism, classism, misogyny, and bigotry directed at gender choice (and why don't we have a succinct word for that type of bias?) or they bodies they are born into. I cannot express the depth of my rage and dismay at Trump and all his enablers, the entrenched male establishment who thinks nothing of piling on additional laws restricting the right of a woman to own her own body - all to aid their grasp (or grope) of power.

Throw the bums out. They're toast.

Random thoughts: This is a(nother) puzzle I started and felt stumped by, but I just kept chipping away at it. After filling in where I could, I rared back and squinted at it. That sometimes helps me see skeletons of possible words and then I can back-form (if that's a word) to see how that word could be an answer to the clue. This time the tactic helped me see CONGER (though I didn't know anago, it sounded like unagi, and conger is an eel) and RATHOLE when each had only two letters to start with.

I found the puzzle challenging and fun, although I never heard of 'hen tracks' being used as a synonym for SCRAWLS. Chicken scratches, yes. Maybe it's an unfamiliar colloquialism?

And thank you for 'RONDELLE,' a glorious mouthful of a satisfying word, conjuring up lovely images of ridgy light-scattering discs of glass. My mother used to do stained glass and I think I remember learning that in former times, to make panes, molten glass was poured out on a flat stone which was then spun to thin out and flatten the glass into a round sheet. The rondelle was the center of the disc of glass which cooled before it got all the way flattened out. This may be magical remembering, but I like the story.

One thing I love about a stimulating puzzle like this one is how relaxing it is when the answers finally fall into place. One small shining piece of order in an increasingly mad, mad, mad, mad world!
